Package mz

Interface MergeInterface<T extends Comparable>

Type Parameters:
T - setting of a type based on which the elements can be sorted.
All Superinterfaces:
Sort<T>
All Known Implementing Classes:
BatcherOddEvenMerge, IntroBatcherOddEvenMerge, IntroDPQBatcherOddEvenMerge, IntroDPQMerge, IntroDPQMerge3, IntroDPQMergeInPlace, IntroDPQMergeInsertion, IntroDPQOddEvenMerge, IntroDPQTim, IntroDPQWeaveMerge, IntroDPQWiki, IntroMerge, IntroMerge3, IntroMergeInPlace, IntroMergeInsertion, IntroOddEvenMerge, IntroTim, IntroWeaveMerge, IntroWiki, Merge, Merge3, MergeInPlace, MergeInsertion, OddEvenMerge, Tim, WeaveMerge, Wiki
public interface MergeInterface<T extends Comparable> extends Sort<T>
MergeInterface, containing the methods of Merge Sort to implement other classes.
Since:
1.0
Author:
Magyar Zolt√°n

    Methods inherited from interface mz.Sort

    sortArray, sortArrayDec, sortArrayInc, sortArrayRev

  • Method Details

    • mergeInc

      default void mergeInc(T[] array)
      mergeInc that performs a Merge Sort on an array of Comparable objects in increasing order. The method recursively divides the array into smaller subarrays, sorts them individually, and then merges them together using the mergingInc method.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and the indices left is 0, mid is (array.length / 2), and right is (array.length - 1) that define the portion of the array to be sorted.
      • The condition if (left < right) checks if the portion of the array has more than one element. If so, it proceeds with the merge sort algorithm.
      • Inside the condition, the method recursively calls itself to sort the left and right halves of the portion.
      • The first recursive call mergeInc(array, left, ((left + mid) / 2), mid) divides the left half of the portion by updating the mid index to be the midpoint between left and mid.
      • The second recursive call mergeInc(array, (mid + 1), (((mid + 1) + right) / 2), right) divides the right half of the portion by updating the mid index to be the midpoint between (mid + 1) and right.
      • After the recursive calls, the mergingInc method is called to merge the two sorted halves together. The mergingInc method takes the array, left, mid, and right indices as arguments.
      • The overall effect of the mergeInc method is to recursively divide the array into smaller subarrays until they consist of individual elements. Then, it merges and sorts these individual elements to gradually build the sorted array.
      mergeInc this implementation follows the divide-and-conquer strategy of merge sort, where the array is recursively divided into smaller subarrays, sorted individually, and then merged back together.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • mergeInc(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • mergeDec

      default void mergeDec(T[] array)
      mergeDec that performs a Merge Sort on an array of Comparable objects in decreasing order. The method recursively divides the array into smaller subarrays, sorts them individually, and then merges them together using the mergingDec method.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and the indices left is 0, mid is (array.length / 2), and right is (array.length - 1) that define the portion of the array to be sorted.
      • The condition if (left < right) checks if the portion of the array has more than one element. If so, it proceeds with the merge sort algorithm.
      • Inside the condition, the method recursively calls itself to sort the left and right halves of the portion.
      • The first recursive call mergeDec(array, left, ((left + mid) / 2), mid) divides the left half of the portion by updating the mid index to be the midpoint between left and mid.
      • The second recursive call mergeDec(array, (mid + 1), (((mid + 1) + right) / 2), right) divides the right half of the portion by updating the mid index to be the midpoint between (mid + 1) and right.
      • After the recursive calls, the mergingDec method is called to merge the two sorted halves together. The mergingDec method takes the array, left, mid, and right indices as arguments.
      • The overall effect of the mergeDec method is to recursively divide the array into greater subarrays until they consist of individual elements. Then, it merges and sorts these individual elements to gradually build the sorted array.
      mergeDec this implementation follows the divide-and-conquer strategy of merge sort, where the array is recursively divided into smaller subarrays, sorted individually, and then merged back together.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • mergeDec(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • mergeInc

      default void mergeInc(T[] array, int left, int mid, int right)
      mergeInc that performs a Merge Sort on an array of Comparable objects in increasing order. The method recursively divides the array into smaller subarrays, sorts them individually, and then merges them together using the mergingInc method.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and the indices left, mid, and right that define the portion of the array to be sorted.
      • The condition if (left < right) checks if the portion of the array has more than one element. If so, it proceeds with the merge sort algorithm.
      • Inside the condition, the method recursively calls itself to sort the left and right halves of the portion.
      • The first recursive call mergeInc(array, left, ((left + mid) / 2), mid) divides the left half of the portion by updating the mid index to be the midpoint between left and mid.
      • The second recursive call mergeInc(array, (mid + 1), (((mid + 1) + right) / 2), right) divides the right half of the portion by updating the mid index to be the midpoint between (mid + 1) and right.
      • After the recursive calls, the mergingInc method is called to merge the two sorted halves together. The mergingInc method takes the array, left, mid, and right indices as arguments.
      • The overall effect of the mergeInc method is to recursively divide the array into smaller subarrays until they consist of individual elements. Then, it merges and sorts these individual elements to gradually build the sorted array.
      mergeInc this implementation follows the divide-and-conquer strategy of merge sort, where the array is recursively divided into smaller subarrays, sorted individually, and then merged back together.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the mid and right value.
      mid - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the right value, and must be greater than the left.
      right - from the array, index value, must be greater than the left and mid value.
      See Also:
      • mergingInc(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • mergeDec

      default void mergeDec(T[] array, int left, int mid, int right)
      mergeDec that performs a Merge Sort on an array of Comparable objects in decreasing order. The method recursively divides the array into smaller subarrays, sorts them individually, and then merges them together using the mergingDec method.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, and the indices left, mid, and right that define the portion of the array to be sorted.
      • The condition if (left < right) checks if the portion of the array has more than one element. If so, it proceeds with the merge sort algorithm.
      • Inside the condition, the method recursively calls itself to sort the left and right halves of the portion.
      • The first recursive call mergeDec(array, left, ((left + mid) / 2), mid) divides the left half of the portion by updating the mid index to be the midpoint between left and mid.
      • The second recursive call mergeDec(array, (mid + 1), (((mid + 1) + right) / 2), right) divides the right half of the portion by updating the mid index to be the midpoint between (mid + 1) and right.
      • After the recursive calls, the mergingDec method is called to merge the two sorted halves together. The mergingDec method takes the array, left, mid, and right indices as arguments.
      • The overall effect of the mergeDec method is to recursively divide the array into greater subarrays until they consist of individual elements. Then, it merges and sorts these individual elements to gradually build the sorted array.
      mergeDec this implementation follows the divide-and-conquer strategy of merge sort, where the array is recursively divided into smaller subarrays, sorted individually, and then merged back together.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the mid and right value.
      mid - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the right value, and must be greater than the left.
      right - from the array, index value, must be greater than the left and mid value.
      See Also:
      • mergingDec(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • mergeInc

      default void mergeInc(T[] array, int left, int right)
      mergeInc method for performing an iterative bottom-up merge sort on an array. It divides the array into subarrays of increasing sizesand merges them together until the entire array is sorted.
      • This while loop iterates until the left index becomes equal to or greater than the right index, indicating that the entire array is sorted.
      • This for loop iterates through the array in increments of (left * 2), effectively dividing the array into subarrays of size (left * 2) for merging.
      • This calculates the indices for the merging operation. mid represents the midpoint of the current subarray, and end represents the ending index of the current subarray or the ending index of the entire array if it's reached before the subarray size.
      • This calls the mergingInc method to merge the subarray defined by the indices i, mid, and end.
      • left *= 2 After each iteration of the outer loop, the left variable is doubled. This increases the size of the subarrays being merged in the next iteration.
      mergeInc method performs an iterative bottom-up merge sort by repeatedly merging subarrays of increasing sizes until the entire array is sorted. It utilizes the mergingInc method to perform the merging operation.
      Parameters:
      array - The array to be sorted.
      left - The starting index of the subarray to be sorted.
      right - The ending index (exclusive) of the subarray to be sorted.
      See Also:
      • mergingInc(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • mergeDec

      default void mergeDec(T[] array, int left, int right)
      mergeDec method for performing an iterative bottom-up merge sort on an array. It divides the array into subarrays of increasing sizesand merges them together until the entire array is sorted.
      • This while loop iterates until the left index becomes equal to or greater than the right index, indicating that the entire array is sorted.
      • This for loop iterates through the array in increments of (left * 2), effectively dividing the array into subarrays of size (left * 2) for merging.
      • This calculates the indices for the merging operation. mid represents the midpoint of the current subarray, and end represents the ending index of the current subarray or the ending index of the entire array if it's reached before the subarray size.
      • This calls the mergingDec method to merge the subarray defined by the indices i, mid, and end.
      • left *= 2 After each iteration of the outer loop, the left variable is doubled. This decreases the size of the subarrays being merged in the next iteration.
      mergeDec method performs an iterative bottom-up merge sort by repeatedly merging subarrays of increasing sizes until the entire array is sorted. It utilizes the mergingDec method to perform the merging operation.
      Parameters:
      array - The array to be sorted.
      left - The starting index of the subarray to be sorted.
      right - The ending index (exclusive) of the subarray to be sorted.
      See Also:

    • mergeInc

      default void mergeInc(T[] array, int left, int right, T[] buffer)
      mergeInc method for performing an iterative bottom-up merge sort on an array. It divides the array into subarrays of increasing sizesand merges them together until the entire array is sorted.
      • This while loop iterates until the left index becomes equal to or greater than the right index, indicating that the entire array is sorted.
      • This for loop iterates through the array in increments of (left * 2), effectively dividing the array into subarrays of size (left * 2) for merging.
      • This calculates the indices for the merging operation. mid represents the midpoint of the current subarray, and end represents the ending index of the current subarray or the ending index of the entire array if it's reached before the subarray size.
      • This calls the mergingInc method to merge the subarray defined by the indices i, mid, and end into the buffer array.
      • left *= 2 After each iteration of the outer loop, the left variable is doubled. This increases the size of the subarrays being merged in the next iteration.
      mergeInc method performs an iterative bottom-up merge sort by repeatedly merging subarrays of increasing sizes until the entire array is sorted. It utilizes the mergingInc method to perform the merging operation.
      Parameters:
      array - The array to be sorted.
      left - The starting index of the subarray to be sorted.
      right - The ending index (exclusive) of the subarray to be sorted.
      buffer - An auxiliary array used for merging.
      See Also:
      • mergingInc(Comparable[], int, int, int, Comparable[])

    • mergeDec

      default void mergeDec(T[] array, int left, int right, T[] buffer)
      mergeDec method for performing an iterative bottom-up merge sort on an array. It divides the array into subarrays of increasing sizesand merges them together until the entire array is sorted.
      • This while loop iterates until the left index becomes equal to or greater than the right index, indicating that the entire array is sorted.
      • This for loop iterates through the array in increments of (left * 2), effectively dividing the array into subarrays of size (left * 2) for merging.
      • This calculates the indices for the merging operation. mid represents the midpoint of the current subarray, and end represents the ending index of the current subarray or the ending index of the entire array if it's reached before the subarray size.
      • This calls the mergingDec method to merge the subarray defined by the indices i, mid, and end into the buffer array.
      • left *= 2 After each iteration of the outer loop, the left variable is doubled. This decreases the size of the subarrays being merged in the next iteration.
      mergeDec method performs an iterative bottom-up merge sort by repeatedly merging subarrays of increasing sizes until the entire array is sorted. It utilizes the mergingDec method to perform the merging operation.
      Parameters:
      array - The array to be sorted.
      left - The starting index of the subarray to be sorted.
      right - The ending index (exclusive) of the subarray to be sorted.
      buffer - An auxiliary array used for merging.

    • mergeInc

      default void mergeInc(T[] array, int left, int mid1, int mid2, int right, T[] buffer)
      mergeInc method for merging three sorted subarrays into a single array. It takes the indices of the subarray boundaries and uses four pointers i, j, k, l to iterate through the subarrays and merge them into a buffer array.
      • @SuppressWarnings("unchecked"): This annotation suppresses unchecked warnings that might occur when using generics, indicating that the code will handle any necessary type checking appropriately.
      • Initializes four pointers i, j, k, l. i points to the current position in the first subarray, j points to the current position in the second subarray, k points to the current position in the third subarray, and l points to the current position in the buffer array.
      • This while loop continues as long as all three subarrays have remaining elements to be processed.
      • This condition checks if the element at position i in the first subarray is less than the element at position j in the second subarray.
      • if (array[i].compareTo(array[k]) < 0): This nested condition checks if the element at position i in the first subarray is also less than the element at position k in the third subarray.
      • If both conditions in steps 5 and 6 are true, the element at position i in the first subarray is copied to the buffer array at position l. Then, both i and l pointers are incremented.
      • If the condition in step 6 is false, the element at position k in the third subarray is selected for merging.
      • The element at position k in the third subarray is copied to the buffer array at position l. Then, both k and l pointers are incremented.
      • If the condition in step 5 is false, the element at position j in the second subarray is selected for merging.
      • if (array[j].compareTo(array[k]) < 0): This nested condition checks if the element at position j in the second subarray is less than the element at position k in the third subarray.
      • If the condition in step 11 is true, the element at position j in the second subarray is copied to the buffer array at position l. Then, both j and l pointers are incremented.
      • If the condition in step 11 is false, the element at position k in the third subarray is selected for merging.
      • The element at position k in the third subarray is copied to the buffer array at position l. Then, both k and l pointers are incremented.
      • The following three while loops merge any remaining elements in pairs of subarrays ((i, j), (j, k), (i, k)) into the buffer array, similar to the previous steps.
      • The remaining three while loops copy any remaining elements from the subarrays i, j, k to the buffer array.
      mergeInc this method merges three sorted subarrays into a single sorted array using four pointers to iterate through the subarrays and merge their elements into a buffer array. The merged elements are then copied back to the original array.
      Parameters:
      array - The array containing the subarrays to be merged.
      left - The starting index of the first subarray.
      mid1 - The ending index (exclusive) of the first subarray.
      mid2 - The ending index (exclusive) of the second subarray.
      right - The ending index (exclusive) of the third subarray.
      buffer - An auxiliary array used for merging.

    • mergeDec

      default void mergeDec(T[] array, int left, int mid1, int mid2, int right, T[] buffer)
      mergeDec method for merging three sorted subarrays into a single array. It takes the indices of the subarray boundaries and uses four pointers i, j, k, l to iterate through the subarrays and merge them into a buffer array.
      • @SuppressWarnings("unchecked"): This annotation suppresses unchecked warnings that might occur when using generics, indicating that the code will handle any necessary type checking appropriately.
      • Initializes four pointers i, j, k, l. i points to the current position in the first subarray, j points to the current position in the second subarray, k points to the current position in the third subarray, and l points to the current position in the buffer array.
      • This while loop continues as long as all three subarrays have remaining elements to be processed.
      • This condition checks if the element at position i in the first subarray is more than the element at position j in the second subarray.
      • if (array[i].compareTo(array[k]) > 0): This nested condition checks if the element at position i in the first subarray is also less than the element at position k in the third subarray.
      • If both conditions in steps 5 and 6 are true, the element at position i in the first subarray is copied to the buffer array at position l. Then, both i and l pointers are incremented.
      • If the condition in step 6 is false, the element at position k in the third subarray is selected for merging.
      • The element at position k in the third subarray is copied to the buffer array at position l. Then, both k and l pointers are incremented.
      • If the condition in step 5 is false, the element at position j in the second subarray is selected for merging.
      • if (array[j].compareTo(array[k]) > 0): This nested condition checks if the element at position j in the second subarray is more than the element at position k in the third subarray.
      • If the condition in step 11 is true, the element at position j in the second subarray is copied to the buffer array at position l. Then, both j and l pointers are incremented.
      • If the condition in step 11 is false, the element at position k in the third subarray is selected for merging.
      • The element at position k in the third subarray is copied to the buffer array at position l. Then, both k and l pointers are incremented.
      • The following three while loops merge any remaining elements in pairs of subarrays ((i, j), (j, k), (i, k)) into the buffer array, similar to the previous steps.
      • The remaining three while loops copy any remaining elements from the subarrays i, j, k to the buffer array.
      mergeInc this method merges three sorted subarrays into a single sorted array using four pointers to iterate through the subarrays and merge their elements into a buffer array. The merged elements are then copied back to the original array.
      Parameters:
      array - The array containing the subarrays to be merged.
      left - The starting index of the first subarray.
      mid1 - The ending index (exclusive) of the first subarray.
      mid2 - The ending index (exclusive) of the second subarray.
      right - The ending index (exclusive) of the third subarray.
      buffer - An auxiliary array used for merging.

    • mergingInc

      default void mergingInc(T[] array, int left, int mid, int right)
      mergingInc that performs a merging operation for the purpose of merging two sorted portions of an array into a single sorted portion. The method assumes that the left portion of the array, from index left to mid, and the right portion, from index (mid + 1) to right, are already sorted in increasing order.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method starts by checking if the indices left, mid, and right are within valid bounds. If the condition left > mid || mid + 1 > right is true, it means that either the left portion or the right portion is empty or the indices are not properly specified. In such cases, the method returns without performing any merging.
      • The variables n1 and n2 are assigned the sizes of the left and right portions, respectively.
      • Two new arrays, leftArray and rightArray, are created using the Arrays.copyOfRange method. These arrays contain copies of the respective portions of the original array.
      • The variables i and j are used as indices to iterate over leftArray and rightArray, respectively.
      • The variable k is used as an index to update the array with the merged elements.
      • The subsequent while loop continues as long as both i and j are within their respective array sizes, n1 and n2. It compares the elements at indices i and j of leftArray and rightArray, respectively, and assigns the smaller element to array[k]. The corresponding index (i or j) and k are incremented accordingly.
      • After the while loop, there might still be remaining elements in either leftArray or rightArray. The next two while loops handle the remaining elements by copying them into array starting from index k.
      • Finally, the merging operation is complete, and the merged sorted portion is stored in the original array from index left to right.
      mergingInc method is commonly used as part of merge sort algorithms to merge two sorted portions of an array into a single sorted portion.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the mid and right value.
      mid - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the right value, and must be greater than the left.
      right - from the array, index value, must be greater than the left and mid value.

    • mergingDec

      default void mergingDec(T[] array, int left, int mid, int right)
      mergingDec that performs a merging operation for the purpose of merging two sorted portions of an array into a single sorted portion. The method assumes that the left portion of the array, from index left to mid, and the right portion, from index (mid + 1) to right, are already sorted in increasing order.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method starts by checking if the indices left, mid, and right are within valid bounds. If the condition left > mid || mid + 1 > right is true, it means that either the left portion or the right portion is empty or the indices are not properly specified. In such cases, the method returns without performing any merging.
      • The variables n1 and n2 are assigned the sizes of the left and right portions, respectively.
      • Two new arrays, leftArray and rightArray, are created using the Arrays.copyOfRange method. These arrays contain copies of the respective portions of the original array.
      • The variables i and j are used as indices to iterate over leftArray and rightArray, respectively.
      • The variable k is used as an index to update the array with the merged elements.
      • The subsequent while loop continues as long as both i and j are within their respective array sizes, n1 and n2. It compares the elements at indices i and j of leftArray and rightArray, respectively, and assigns the greater element to array[k]. The corresponding index (i or j) and k are incremented accordingly.
      • After the while loop, there might still be remaining elements in either leftArray or rightArray. The next two while loops handle the remaining elements by copying them into array starting from index k.
      • Finally, the merging operation is complete, and the merged sorted portion is stored in the original array from index left to right.
      mergingDec method is commonly used as part of merge sort algorithms to merge two sorted portions of an array into a single sorted portion.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the mid and right value.
      mid - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the right value, and must be greater than the left.
      right - from the array, index value, must be greater than the left and mid value.

    • mergingInc

      default void mergingInc(T[] array, int left, int mid, int right, T[] buffer)
      mergingInc method for merging two sorted subarrays within an array using the merge sort algorithm.
      • @SuppressWarnings("unchecked"): This annotation suppresses unchecked warnings that might occur when using generics, indicating that the code will handle any necessary type checking appropriately.
      • Initializes two pointers n1 and n2 to keep track of the current positions within the subarrays to be merged. n1 is initially set to the leftmost index, and n2 is set to the index immediately after the midpoint.
      • This loop iterates from the left index to the right index (inclusive) to merge the subarrays.
      • This condition checks if the current element at position n1 in the left subarray is less than or equal to the current element at position n2 in the right subarray. It also checks if the n2 pointer has reached the end of the right subarray. If either of these conditions is true, the element at n1 is selected for merging.
      • If the condition in the previous step is true, the element at position n1 in the left subarray is copied to the buffer array at position i. Then, the n1 pointer is incremented.
      • If the condition in step 5 is false, the element at position n2 in the right subarray is selected for merging.
      • The element at position n2 in the right subarray is copied to the buffer array at position i. Then, the n2 pointer is incremented.
      • Once the merging is complete, the merged elements in the buffer array are copied back to the original array starting from the left index. The number of elements to copy is (right - left + 1).
      mergingInc this method performs the merging step of the merge sort algorithm by comparing elements from two sorted subarrays and merging them into a temporary buffer array. After the merging is complete, the merged elements are copied back System.arraycopy to the original array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - The index of the leftmost element of the subarray to be merged.
      mid - The index of the midpoint element in the subarray to be merged.
      right - The index of the rightmost element of the subarray to be merged.
      buffer - An auxiliary array used for storing the merged elements temporarily.

    • mergingDec

      default void mergingDec(T[] array, int left, int mid, int right, T[] buffer)
      mergingDec method for merging two sorted subarrays within an array using the merge sort algorithm.
      • @SuppressWarnings("unchecked"): This annotation suppresses unchecked warnings that might occur when using generics, indicating that the code will handle any necessary type checking appropriately.
      • Initializes two pointers n1 and n2 to keep track of the current positions within the subarrays to be merged. n1 is initially set to the leftmost index, and n2 is set to the index immediately after the midpoint.
      • This loop iterates from the left index to the right index (inclusive) to merge the subarrays.
      • This condition checks if the current element at position n1 in the left subarray is more than or equal to the current element at position n2 in the right subarray. It also checks if the n2 pointer has reached the end of the right subarray. If either of these conditions is true, the element at n1 is selected for merging.
      • If the condition in the previous step is true, the element at position n1 in the left subarray is copied to the buffer array at position i. Then, the n1 pointer is incremented.
      • If the condition in step 5 is false, the element at position n2 in the right subarray is selected for merging.
      • The element at position n2 in the right subarray is copied to the buffer array at position i. Then, the n2 pointer is incremented.
      • Once the merging is complete, the merged elements in the buffer array are copied back to the original array starting from the left index. The number of elements to copy is (right - left + 1).
      mergingDec this method performs the merging step of the merge sort algorithm by comparing elements from two sorted subarrays and merging them into a temporary buffer array. After the merging is complete, the merged elements are copied back System.arraycopy to the original array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - The index of the leftmost element of the subarray to be merged.
      mid - The index of the midpoint element in the subarray to be merged.
      right - The index of the rightmost element of the subarray to be merged.
      buffer - An auxiliary array used for storing the merged elements temporarily.

    • mergingInc

      default void mergingInc(T[] array, T[] leftArray, T[] rightArray)
      mergingInc method for merging two sorted subarrays into a single array.
      • @SuppressWarnings("unchecked"): This annotation suppresses unchecked warnings that might occur when using generics, indicating that the code will handle any necessary type checking appropriately.
      • Initializes three pointers i, j, k. i points to the current position in the left subarray, j points to the current position in the right subarray, and k points to the current position in the merged array.
      • This while loop continues as long as both i and j are within the bounds of their respective subarrays.
      • if (leftArray[i].compareTo(rightArray[j]) < 0): This condition checks if the element at position i in the left subarray is less than the element at position j in the right subarray. If true, the element from the left subarray is selected for merging.
      • If the condition in the previous step is true, the element at position i in the left subarray is copied to the array at position k. Then, all three pointers i, j, k are incremented.
      • If the condition in step 5 is false, the element at position j in the right subarray is selected for merging.
      • The element at position j in the right subarray is copied to the array at position k. Then, all three pointers i, j, k are incremented.
      • This while loop copies any remaining elements in the left subarray to the array if there are any.
      • The remaining element at position i in the left subarray is copied to the array at position k. Then, both i and k pointers are incremented.
      • This loop copies any remaining elements in the right subarray to the array if there are any.
      • The remaining element at position j in the right subarray is copied to the array at position k. Then, both j and k pointers are incremented.
      mergingInc this method merges two sorted subarrays leftArray and rightArray into a single sorted array array. It compares elements from both subarrays and copies them to the array in the correct order until one of the subarrays is fully processed. Then, it copies any remaining elements from the unfinished subarray to the array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      leftArray - The left subarray that is sorted in ascending order.
      rightArray - The right subarray that is sorted in ascending order.

    • mergingDec

      default void mergingDec(T[] array, T[] leftArray, T[] rightArray)
      mergingDec method for merging two sorted subarrays into a single array.
      • @SuppressWarnings("unchecked"): This annotation suppresses unchecked warnings that might occur when using generics, indicating that the code will handle any necessary type checking appropriately.
      • Initializes three pointers i, j, k. i points to the current position in the left subarray, j points to the current position in the right subarray, and k points to the current position in the merged array.
      • This while loop continues as long as both i and j are within the bounds of their respective subarrays.
      • if (leftArray[i].compareTo(rightArray[j]) > 0): This condition checks if the element at position i in the left subarray is more than the element at position j in the right subarray. If true, the element from the left subarray is selected for merging.
      • If the condition in the previous step is true, the element at position i in the left subarray is copied to the array at position k. Then, all three pointers i, j, k are incremented.
      • If the condition in step 5 is false, the element at position j in the right subarray is selected for merging.
      • The element at position j in the right subarray is copied to the array at position k. Then, all three pointers i, j, k are incremented.
      • This while loop copies any remaining elements in the left subarray to the array if there are any.
      • The remaining element at position i in the left subarray is copied to the array at position k. Then, both i and k pointers are incremented.
      • This loop copies any remaining elements in the right subarray to the array if there are any.
      • The remaining element at position j in the right subarray is copied to the array at position k. Then, both j and k pointers are incremented.
      mergingDec this method merges two sorted subarrays leftArray and rightArray into a single sorted array array. It compares elements from both subarrays and copies them to the array in the correct order until one of the subarrays is fully processed. Then, it copies any remaining elements from the unfinished subarray to the array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      leftArray - The left subarray that is sorted in descending order.
      rightArray - The right subarray that is sorted in descending order.
